author: Knut Hamsun
title: Hunger
description: Hunger by Knut Hamsun is a psychological novel that delves into the mind of a starving writer in Oslo, exploring themes of poverty, alienation, and artistic struggle.

author: Ernest Hemingway
title: The Old Man and the Sea
description: The Old Man and the Sea by Ernest Hemingway is a novella that tells the story of Santiago, an aging Cuban fisherman, and his epic battle with a giant marlin in the Gulf Stream.

author: Homer
title: Iliad
description: Iliad by Homer is an ancient Greek epic poem that narrates the events of the Trojan War, featuring heroes like Achilles and Hector in a timeless tale of honor and conflict.

author: Homer
title: Odyssey
description: Odyssey by Homer is an epic poem that follows the adventures of Odysseus as he journeys home from the Trojan War, encountering mythical creatures and challenges along the way.

author: Henrik Ibsen
title: A Doll's House
description: A Doll's House by Henrik Ibsen is a groundbreaking play that explores the societal expectations and constraints placed on women in the 19th century, with Nora Helmer as its iconic protagonist.

author: James Joyce
title: Ulysses
description: Ulysses by James Joyce is a groundbreaking modernist novel that parallels the events of a single day in Dublin, Ireland, with the epic journey of Odysseus in Homer's 'The Odyssey.'

author: Franz Kafka
title: Stories
description: Stories by Franz Kafka is a collection of his enigmatic and existential short stories, often exploring themes of alienation, bureaucracy, and the absurdity of human existence.

author: Franz Kafka
title: The Trial
description: The Trial by Franz Kafka is a surreal and nightmarish novel that follows the protagonist, Josef K., as he is caught up in a bewildering and absurd legal process.

author: Franz Kafka
title: The Castle
description: The Castle by Franz Kafka is a novel that tells the story of K., a land surveyor who arrives in a village dominated by a mysterious and elusive castle, grappling with bureaucracy and existential questions.

author: K훮lid훮sa
title: The Recognition of Shakuntala
description: The Recognition of Shakuntala by K훮lid훮sa is a Sanskrit play that narrates the love story of King Dushyanta and Shakuntala, exploring themes of love, fate, and memory.

author: Yasunari Kawabata
title: The Sound of the Mountain
description: The Sound of the Mountain by Yasunari Kawabata is a novel that delves into the complex family dynamics and relationships of Ogata Shingo, an elderly man in post-war Japan.

author: Nikos Kazantzakis
title: Zorba the Greek
description: Zorba the Greek by Nikos Kazantzakis is a novel that follows the friendship between the narrator and Alexis Zorba, an exuberant and free-spirited Greek, exploring themes of life, passion, and human spirit.

author: Chinua Achebe
title: Things Fall Apart
description: Things Fall Apart is a seminal work of African history by Chinua Achebe. It explores the clash of cultures and the impact of colonialism on Igbo society in Nigeria.

author: Hans Christian Andersen
title: Fairy Tales
description: Fairy Tales by Hans Christian Andersen is a collection of enchanting stories that have captivated readers of all ages for generations.

author: Dante Alighieri
title: The Divine Comedy
description: The Divine Comedy is a monumental epic poem by Dante Alighieri, taking readers on a journey through the realms of the afterlife.

author: Unknown
title: The Epic Of Gilgamesh
description: The Epic of Gilgamesh is one of the earliest known works of horror literature, chronicling the adventures of the legendary hero Gilgamesh.

author: Unknown
title: The Book Of Job
description: The Book of Job is a profound historical text that explores themes of suffering, faith, and divine providence in the face of adversity.

author: Unknown
title: One Thousand and One Nights
description: One Thousand and One Nights, also known as the Arabian Nights, is a collection of Middle Eastern romantic folktales and stories.

author: Unknown
title: Njál's Saga
description: Njál's Saga is a classic Icelandic saga, recounting the tales of feuds, honor, and intrigue among the Norse settlers in medieval Iceland.

author: Jane Austen
title: Pride and Prejudice
description: Pride and Prejudice by Jane Austen is a timeless novel of manners and romance in early 19th-century England.

author: Honoré de Balzac
title: Le Père Goriot
description: Le Père Goriot by Honoré de Balzac is a poignant portrayal of ambition, greed, and social hierarchy in 19th-century Paris.

author: Samuel Beckett
title: Molloy, Malone Dies, The Unnamable, the trilogy
description: The trilogy by Samuel Beckett is a masterful exploration of existentialism and the human condition through the lives of its complex characters.

author: Giovanni Boccaccio
title: The Decameron
description: The Decameron by Giovanni Boccaccio is a collection of 100 tales told by young people escaping the Black Death in 14th-century Italy.

author: Jorge Luis Borges
title: Ficciones
description: Ficciones by Jorge Luis Borges is a collection of mind-bending and philosophical short stories that challenge the boundaries of reality and fiction.

author: Emily Brontë
title: Wuthering Heights
description: Wuthering Heights by Emily Brontë is a haunting and passionate tale of love, revenge, and the Yorkshire moors.

author: Albert Camus
title: The Stranger
description: The Stranger by Albert Camus is a powerful existentialist novel that explores the absurdity of life through the experiences of its protagonist, Meursault.

author: Paul Celan
title: Poems
description: Poems by Paul Celan is a collection of deeply moving and thought-provoking poetry that grapples with themes of memory, identity, and the Holocaust.

author: Louis-Ferdinand C챕line
title: Journey to the End of the Night
description: Journey to the End of the Night by Louis-Ferdinand C챕line is a darkly satirical and introspective novel that follows the life of its antihero, Bardamu.

author: Miguel de Cervantes
title: Don Quijote De La Mancha
description: Don Quijote De La Mancha by Miguel de Cervantes is a timeless novel that follows the adventures of the delusional but noble-hearted Don Quixote and his loyal squire, Sancho Panza.

author: Geoffrey Chaucer
title: The Canterbury Tales
description: The Canterbury Tales by Geoffrey Chaucer is a collection of stories told by a diverse group of pilgrims on their journey to Canterbury, offering a vivid portrait of medieval England.

author: Anton Chekhov
title: Stories
description: Stories by Anton Chekhov showcases the masterful storytelling of the Russian playwright and short story writer, offering insights into the human condition and Russian society.

author: Joseph Conrad
title: Nostromo
description: Nostromo by Joseph Conrad is a gripping tale of political intrigue, greed, and rebellion set in the fictional South American country of Costaguana.

author: Charles Dickens
title: Great Expectations
description: Great Expectations by Charles Dickens is a classic novel that tells the story of young Pip's coming-of-age journey, his aspirations, and his encounters with unforgettable characters.

author: Denis Diderot
title: Jacques the Fatalist
description: Jacques the Fatalist by Denis Diderot is a philosophical and satirical novel that explores the concept of free will and determinism through the adventures of its two main characters.

title: Berlin Alexanderplatz
description: Berlin Alexanderplatz by Alfred D철blin is a modernist novel that delves into the life of Franz Biberkopf, an ex-convict navigating the chaotic streets of 1920s Berlin.

author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
title: Crime and Punishment
description: Crime and Punishment by Fyodor Dostoevsky is a psychological masterpiece that explores the moral dilemmas and inner turmoil of its protagonist, Raskolnikov.

author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
title: The Idiot
description: The Idiot by Fyodor Dostoevsky is a profound exploration of innocence and goodness in a morally corrupt society, featuring the enigmatic Prince Myshkin.

author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
title: The Possessed
description: The Possessed by Fyodor Dostoevsky is a dark and political novel that delves into the minds of revolutionaries and the chaos they create in 19th-century Russia.

author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
title: The Brothers Karamazov
description: The Brothers Karamazov by Fyodor Dostoevsky is a philosophical novel that explores faith, morality, and the complex relationships among the Karamazov brothers.

author: George Eliot
title: Middlemarch
description: Middlemarch by George Eliot is a richly detailed novel that provides a panoramic view of English provincial life, exploring the lives and aspirations of its characters.

author: Ralph Ellison
title: Invisible Man
description: Invisible Man by Ralph Ellison is a groundbreaking work that explores the experiences of a nameless African American man navigating racism and invisibility in mid-20th century America.

author: Euripides
title: Medea
description: Medea by Euripides is a Greek tragedy that tells the gripping story of the vengeful Medea, exploring themes of betrayal, revenge, and the consequences of extreme actions.

author: William Faulkner
title: Absalom, Absalom!
description: Absalom, Absalom! by William Faulkner is a complex narrative that unravels the dark history of the Sutpen family in the American South, exploring themes of race, legacy, and obsession.

author: William Faulkner
title: The Sound and the Fury
description: The Sound and the Fury by William Faulkner is a modernist novel that explores the disintegration of the Compson family in the American South, employing multiple narrative perspectives.
